plan: I wouldn't necessarily regret my bid in either scenario. If others bid much lower and I win, it’s part of my strategy to test different bid levels for data-gathering, at potentially high profit but also high risks. If others bid way higher and I lose, I've learned about my competitors' willingness to bid high. My bidding strategy will vary in each round, based on past results. I’ll experiment with low, medium, and high-risk level bids, from close to $0 to the upper limit of $99. As I gather more data, I'll refine my strategy for profit maximization. My final bid this round is $77.

In a case where others bid lower, I don't regret my bid as it allows me to secure the prize adding to my profit. If others bid higher and I lose, I do not regret either as my goal is long-term profit, losing a single round isn't a failure. My final bid would depend on my value, but aiming for a higher end seems reasonable. In subsequent rounds, I'd test aggressive strategies such as bidding closer to my value when it's high and safe strategies by bidding lower when it's moderate. I would also observe bidding tendencies of Andy and Charles to adjust my bid accordingly.

In cases where the other bidders bid lower, I wouldn't regret my bid since I won the auction. However, I run the risk of overpaying based on the others' valuations. In cases where the other bidders bid higher, I'd only regret bidding low if my value was significantly higher than their bids. As a top priority, my bidding strategies would incorporate diverse tactics to maximize profit. First, I'll analyze bidding behaviors from past rounds and adapt accordingly. Secondly, I'll be unafraid to gamble with high-risk, high-reward strategies. My final bid for this round is data-driven but encapsulates an element of unpredictability to keep competitors guessing.
